Coccidioides posadasii RMSCC 3488 is a dimorphic fungal species that belongs to the genus Coccidioides. It is the causative agent of coccidioidomycosis, also known as Valley Fever, a respiratory disease primarily found in the southwestern United States and parts of Mexico.

The RMSCC 3488 strain is a clinical isolate of C. posadasii, a species that is genetically distinct from the closely related Coccidioides immitis. C. posadasii is known to have a more restricted geographic distribution, primarily found in the Sonoran Desert region.

In its mycelial form, the fungus grows as a septate, hyaline hyphae that can produce arthroconidia, which are infectious spores. When inhaled, the arthroconidia can transform into spherical, thick-walled structures called spherules within the host's lungs. These spherules undergo endosporulation, eventually rupturing and releasing endospores, which can then disseminate and infect other host cells.

The RMSCC 3488 strain has been used in various research studies to understand the pathogenesis, epidemiology, and host-pathogen interactions of Coccidioides species, contributing to the overall understanding of coccidioidomycosis and the development of improved diagnostic and treatment strategies.
